div.p:
At a meeting of the Trustees of Royal Park, Melbourne, on 16 July 1863, M 'stated, that he had as honorary Secretary deemed it his duty to summon his colleagues, in order that an opportunity might be afforded to them of expressing an opinion wether cognizance should be taken of the sale of the Dromedaries as proposed by the Council of the Acclimation Society and of which proposition no intimation had been given to the Trustees. Letters on the subject from W. Wardell Esq and Clem. Hodgkinson Esq. were read deprecating the inteded sale of those useful animals. After a lengthened deliberation it was resolved that the honorary Secretary should apply to the honorable the Chief Secretary for information wether the Trustees might regard themselves perfectly free of any responsibility of this transaction.' (A345, p. 123).
See also M to W. Archer, 17 July 1863 (in this edition as 63-07-17a). Melbourne botanic Gardens
